I had modified a source file that contained the breakpoint in a Tomcat webapp.
Probably the class was reloading while disabling breakpoint.

There are a couple issues here that need investigation:

(1) We are blocking the UI thread to disable breakpoints
(2) JavaBreakpoint.removeRequests(...) (line 649) catches RuntimeException 
which is bad practice. It should limit itself to JDI exceptions.

We have fixed some "invalid stack frame exception" (not sure about this one, 
but it's not what the bug report is about).

We have code to look for JDI exceptions in JDIDebugElement.internalError(). We 
may be able to delegate to the debug target to log or re-throw the exception.

Yikes. The code in JDIDebugElement is scary (even though I think I wrote it :P). Instead of 
maintaining a hard-coded list of "JDI exceptions," we should probably be doing the name check 
that I suggested above.

Fixed RuntimeException catching/logging in JDIDebugElement and JavaBreakpoint as
per above comments.

Please verify, DW.

The new check does not account for "org.eclispe.jdi.TimeoutException". This 
exception is a JDI exception specific to our JDI client.

Righto. Many more changes this time around. I went through the entire breakpoint
hierarchy and updated every location that we catch RuntimeException so that we
now call JDIDebugElement#internalError(...), which has the same "check and
re-throw" logic. In order to have access to a debug element, I had to do some
refactoring to pass the debug target into some methods.
Affected breakpoint classes:
JavaBreakpoint.java
JavaClassPrepareBreakpoint.java
JavaExceptionBreakpoint.java
JavaLineBreakpoint.java
JavaMethodBreakpoint.java
JavaMethodEntryBreakpoint.java
JavaStratumLineBreakpoint.java
JavaWatchpoint.java
Also:
JDIDebugElement - Added check for TimeoutException in addition to the JDI exceptions

Please verify, DW.

Verified. I will open a new bug to deal with breakpoint enablement changes in 
the UI thread (this should be done in a background thread/job).
